HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS:

NAME                       UN ID #               FORM            PACKAGE / CONTAINER          MAX. HEALTH QUANT. RISK

Chlorine 7782-50-5      1017                   Gas/ Liquid     2,000 lb. Cylinder                      16,000 lbs *

* HEALTH RISK: TOXIC (POISONOUS); May be fatal if inhaled or absorbed through skin. Fire will produce irritating, corrosive and / or toxic gases. Contact with gas or liquefied gas may cause burns, severe injury and / or frostbite.

PRIMARY ACTIVITIES: Chlorine at the water treatment plant is used to treat raw water from Laurel River to make potable drinking water for the City of Corbin and the surronding areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION: EMERGENCY REPONSE POLICY: City Utilities Commission is committed to Safety and the implementation of safety procedures. Chlorine tanks at the water treatment plant are housed in a separate building. The Chlorine building is equipped with an alarm system to nofity employees of leaks, vents close if alarms

sounds, containing chemical inside building. Employees are trained in the use of the Class B repair kit (A KIT USE TO CONTROL LEAKS AROUND VALVES).

MANAGEMENT IN SAFETY: General Manager Ronald W. Herd is committed to safety and the implementation of safety  procedures at City Utilities Commission. Each year City Utilties Commission holds an emergency management meeting at the Corbin City Hall with the Corbin Fire Department, Corbin City Police Department, and Whitley County Emergency Management. The topic of disscussion, action to be taken in the event of a chemical release at Water Treatment Plant. The meetings are open to the public.

REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED AT WATER TREATMENT PLANT: The Water treatment plant is located on Hinkle Street just off Highway 312 (Gordon Hill). The water treatment plant potable drinking water for the city of Corbin and the surrounding area. Chlorine is used to treat water brought into the plant from Laurel River intake on Old City Dam Road. The water treatment plant house eight (8) cylinders at a weight of 2,000 lbs. Each. The water plant employs three (3) full time employees and one (1) part-time employee. Two (2) employees hold degrees in chemistry.

PROTECTIVE ACTION IN CASE OF A CHEMICAL RELEASE: Worst-case release scenario, in the event of a chemical release from a 2,000 lb. Chlorine tank at the water treatment plant, all local residents in a 3.50 mile area would be ask to evacuate by local radio stations WKDP and WCTT along with police and fire department employees going door to door. A release of this size will require the expertise of level III agency.

If a leak occurs between the chlorine building and main building, the emergency shut-off valve will close, and the excess flow valve will divert the overflow.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTROY: City Utilities Commission has not had a chemical accident in the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: In the event of a spill or release, radio stations WKDP and WCTT along with

police and fire sirens will be utilized to notify residence to evacuate. Also, police and fire personel will go door to door to insure the evacuation of all affected residents. Schools and churches may be used as shelters if necessity arises.

Baptist Regional Medical Center has a decontamination unit specifically trained in chemical emergencies, and will accept patients contaminated with chlorine and have the capability to provide appropriate care, they are equipped with a heliport for the immediate transport of patients if needed.

The primary respone point is the facility's gate. If this is impractical, the alternate response point is the northeast corner of Kentucky State Route 312 (Gordon Hill) and Highland Avenue. At either response point the facility representative will have in hand a copy of the facility Title III, and appropriate MSDS and be prepared to brief response personnel. Support units will report and await assignment by local organizations.

Actions will be taken for protection of emergency workers on-site and populated area off site. These actions will depend upon the amount of chemical, weather conidtions and other hazards involved, such as fire.

Entry into the evacuated are will be restricted until the highest-ranking official reprensting the city of Corbin, Kentucky, (i.e. Mayor, Mayor Pro-term of City Commissioners) determine it permissible for authorized personnel to enter.

RESPONSE LEVELS: 

LEVEL I: Emergency Condition Description:

An incident or threat of a release which can be controlled by the first response agencies and does not require evacuation of other than the involved structure or outdoor area. The incident is confined to small area and does not pose a immediate threat to life or property. Contact local response agency's fire, police, medical, and any appropriate persons.

LEVEL II: Limited Emergency Condition Description:

An incident involving a greater or larger area which poses a potential threat to life and property and whi

ch may reguire a limited evacuation of the surrounding area. Contact all agencies in Level I plus; HAZMAT TEAM, EOC STAFF, PUBLIC WORKS DEPT., RED CROSS, COUNTY DES/EMA, STATE POLICE, AND PUBLIC UTILITIES.

LEVEL III: Full Emergency Condition Description:

An incident involving a severe hazard or large area which poses an extreme threat to life and property and will probably and will probably reguire large scale evacuation, or an incident requiring the expertise or resources of county, state, federal or private agencies. Contact all Level I and Level II agencies plus the following: MUTUAL AID, STATE DES, HREPS, HSC,USEPA, ATSDR, PEMA, AND OSC/RRT.

FACILITY EQUIPMENT:

Self-contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA), Chemical Suits, Chlorine Alarm System, Chemical Respirator's, Gas Monitors, Three Canister Breathing Apparatus.

COMMUNITY EQUIPMENT:

City of Corbin Fire Department along with West Knox Fire Department are equipped with Self-Contained Breathing Units, and trained in First Aid and CPR. (Both - Level I Agency)

FACILITY TRAINING:

At present City Utilities Commission has seven (7) employees trained in use of Respirator's, SCBAs, and the Class B repair kits.

FACILITY EXERCISE PROGRAM:

Our facility at present has had on-site exercises but none on the county level.

SPILL CONTAIMENT:

In the event of a Chlorine release inside of the chlorine building the product could be contained with the building thereby controlling the release of the product into the atmosphere.

For personel protection, keep upwind, wear appropriate class A or B type protective clothing to include boots, protective gloves and goggles and use proper breathing apparatus. Avoid breathing vapors or dust/ Wash away any material which may have contacted the body with copious amounts of plain water or soap and water.

CLEAN UP:

The Water treatment personnel will accomplish the clean up of any chemical residue, any residue will be put in plastic bags and placed in 55 gallon drums for storage and p

roper disposal.

The Kentucky D.N.R. will approve disposal of waste.

MSDS - (Chlorine) the following steps should be taken in the event of a chlorine spill or leak. Move unprotected personnel upwind. If a chlorine is leaking try to position it so that gas, rather than liquid leaks. Using full protective equipment, apply emergency - sealing device if possible. Cover leaks with tarpaulin or plastic sheet to limit spread of chlorine.
